body: Along a narrow hallway deep inside the Beaux Arts palace known as the New-York Historical Society, there is a single wall of artifacts from 100 years ago. It tells the story of food in New York City at the turn of this century. And it inspires a peculiar sense of deja vu. There is a produce list from a downtown market, featuring sorrel and
title: Food as Ritual, Dining as Theater; Then as Now, New York Sates Its Hungers in Public

body: The man who went out with a pregnant Baruch College student on the day she vanished last month was questioned by the police for the first time yesterday, but there were no indications afterward that investigators were any closer to solving the mystery of her disappearance. Ten days after Kristine Kupka, 28, left the Brooklyn home she shares with
title: No Clues to Missing Student As Her Friend Is Questioned

body: A man who went out with a pregnant Baruch College student on the afternoon she vanished 10 days ago has hired a lawyer and refused to talk to the police about her disappearance or her family's assertions that he fathered her unborn child and, against her wishes, wanted it aborted, investigators said yesterday. ''He's not talking, he's not
title: Man Refuses to Talk to Police About Missing Student

body: Last Saturday shortly after 1 P.M., Kristine Kupka, a 28-year-old senior honor student at Baruch College who is five months pregnant, left the Brooklyn house she shares with five roommates for an afternoon outing with a man her family says is the father of her unborn child. She did not return. Wholly at odds with her character, relatives say, Ms.
title: Pregnant Honor Student Is Missing, Family Says

body: Though they have a common history, the Holocaust victims who gathered last week at Weis's restaurant on Coney Island Avenue did not know each other well. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: KENSINGTON; Urging People to Share and Dispel Their Old Sorrows

body: New York City is the capital of the new global economy and also America's traditional port of immigration. Put these together and you get, as Deborah Sontag and Celia Dugger have vividly reported in The Times this week, a new phenomenon of people living in two homelands, old and new, virtually at once. Previous immigrants remembered and even
title: The New Immigrant Experience

body: RAFI ZABOR was unknown to most readers in April when his first novel, ''The Bear Comes Home,'' won the 1998 PEN/Faulkner Award for fiction, one of the nation's highest literary honors. In a scene worthy of the old television show ''Queen for a Day,'' which crowned a hard-luck nobody and showered her with prizes, Mr. Zabor was whisked out of his
title: Who Is Rafi Zabor?

body: The lifeblood tenant for a commercial broker in neighborhood shopping districts of the city is the chain retailer, perhaps a fast-food outlet or a pharmacy. When the chains are aggressively seeking additional sites, brokers make leases. ''The pharmacy chains are the ones going full speed ahead just now,'' said Joe Battista, a broker with Friedland
title: Commercial Real Estate; Laundries, Coin or Not, Branch Out

body: There are not many places where you can win a gift set of Torah cards or a teeth cleaning just for knowing a few things about Benjamin Franklin. ''Good Question,'' a new call-in radio quiz program on historical figures, is just such a place. The program, created by WMCA (570 AM) and broadcast from 8 to 9 on Saturday nights, is one of the few
title: Radio Quiz Rewards Its Erudite Listeners

body: SATURDAY is not Nathilee Caldeira's Sabbath, yet she feels a certain reverence for the day. As Orthodox Jews dressed for worship walk to synagogues, she and other blacks in the neighborhood go about their business. They do so with an understanding that it is a sacred day. ''Somehow on Saturdays, nobody really gets crazy,'' she said. Sunday is Ms.
title: Old Places, New Faces

body: A 57-year-old livery cab driver who was held up by a gunman inside his taxi in Brooklyn yesterday morning fought back and was shot three times during a struggle in which he managed to disarm his assailant and, despite his wounds, hold the suspect at gunpoint until help arrived, the police said. When the police arrived at the scene they found the
title: Cabdriver, Shot 3 Times, Captures Armed Robber, Police Say

body: Years ago, a Hasidic businessman, now the garrulous father of 14, had made enough money as a salesman to flee Borough Park for a leafy suburb with grand, commodious houses. But he stayed put, expanding his Brooklyn home forward, backward, upward and even downward until it morphed into an urban mansion, complete with household staff and voice-mail
title: Orthodox Neighborhood Reshapes Itself
